citations.narrative:
* At 10:00 PM on March 31, 2023, the licensee placed an adult male Corgi named JJ into a plastic tub used to give baths
to the dogs. After JJ was placed in the tub he jumped out of the tub and landed on the floor that was 33 to 34 inches
below the top of the tub. The licensee stated that when the dog landed both back legs went directly backwards. The
licensee stated that they got JJ to its feet and upon closer examination, found nothing wrong. The dog was able to walk
on its own. The dog was returned to its enclosure. At 4:30 AM on April 1, 2023, the licensee went to load JJ into an
enclosure to be taken to a dog show. When JJ came out of his enclosure, he was observed dragging both back legs
behind him and placing no weight on the back legs. All animals need to be secured in a manner so that no physical harm
is done to the dogs. Not having the dog secured in the wash tub could lead to the dog jumping out of the tub causing
injury, trauma or physical harm to the dog. The licensee must ensure that all animals will be handled in a manner that
does not cause trauma, overheating and excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary discomfort.
To be corrected by end of business 10/2/23.

* Documentation of medical records for an adult male Corgi named JJ did not include the names and dates of treatments
administrated. The licensee stated that JJ was placed on a pill that was given 2 times a day per the directions of the
attending veterinarian. The licensee stated that JJ was given the pill from April 1 thru May 10, 2023. Medical records are
necessary to document treatments being given. The licensee must keep copies of medical records on all animals and
make the records available for APHIS inspection. Correct by 10/12/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
* At 10:00 PM on March 31, 2023, the licensee placed an adult male Corgi named JJ into a plastic tub used to give baths 
to the dogs. After JJ was placed in the tub he jumped out of the tub and landed on the floor that was 33 to 34 inches 
below the top of the tub. The licensee stated that when the dog landed both back legs went directly backwards. The 
licensee stated that they got JJ to its feet and upon closer examination, found nothing wrong. The dog was able to walk 
on its own. The dog was returned to its enclosure. At 4:30 AM on April 1, 2023, the licensee went to load JJ into an 
enclosure to be taken to a dog show. When JJ came out of his enclosure, he was observed dragging both back legs 
behind him and placing no weight on the back legs. All animals need to be secured in a manner so that no physical harm 
is done to the dogs. Not having the dog secured in the wash tub could lead to the dog jumping out of the tub causing 
injury, trauma or physical harm to the dog. The licensee must ensure that all animals will be handled in a manner that 
does not cause trauma, overheating and excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary discomfort. 
To be corrected by end of business 10/2/23. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* Documentation of medical records for an adult male Corgi named JJ did not include the names and dates of treatments 
administrated. The licensee stated that JJ was placed on a pill that was given 2 times a day per the directions of the 
attending veterinarian. The licensee stated that JJ was given the pill from April 1 thru May 10, 2023. Medical records are 
necessary to document treatments being given. The licensee must keep copies of medical records on all animals and 
make the records available for APHIS inspection. Correct by 10/12/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
